title: 113_s2100
content: The Act is titled the "Clean Cookstoves and Fuels Support Act" and includes findings related to clean cookstoves and fuels. Congress finds that nearly half the world's population cooks over open fires or inefficient cookstoves, leading to health issues like respiratory illnesses and increased mortality rates from exposure to smoke. Household air pollution from cookstoves is a significant health risk factor, causing millions of deaths and illnesses annually. The use of biomass cooking fuel contributes to environmental degradation and loss of biodiversity in regions like Asia and Africa. Recent studies show that black carbon from biomass cookstoves contributes to regional air pollution and climate change, with emissions accounting for 21 percent of the global inventory. Women and children spend significant time collecting biomass fuel, facing risks like gender-based violence and rape. The Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves aims to enable the adoption of clean and efficient stoves in 100 million homes by 2020 through a public-private partnership. The United States Government has committed up to $125 million to the sector for research, field implementation activities, and financing. The Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves aims to enable the adoption of clean and efficient stoves in 100 million homes by 2020 through a public-private partnership. The United States Government has committed up to $50,000,000 in financing through various departments for this initiative. The Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and Overseas Private Investment Corporation have committed funding through fiscal years 2015 and 2016 to support projects that provide clean and affordable energy access through the manufacture and sale of cookstoves. This commitment includes research on cookstoves performance, marketing, health benefits, and field expansion. The Alliance for Clean Cookstoves has received additional Federal support from various agencies including the Department of Agriculture, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and the Peace Corps. The Millennium Challenge Corporation made a significant investment of $45,300,000 in Mongolia in 2010 to promote economic growth through energy efficiency and improved air quality. The Alliance for Clean Cookstoves receives Federal support from various agencies to promote economic growth through energy efficiency and improved air quality. The Secretary of State, in collaboration with several federal agencies and international organizations, will support the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves by conducting research, promoting technology adoption, and establishing industry standards for efficient and clean cookstoves. The Secretary of State, federal agencies, and international organizations will support the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves by ensuring efficiency and cleanliness standards are met, engaging diplomatically to promote a commercial market for clean cookstoves and fuels, developing projects to build commercial businesses for clean cookstoves, and providing financing or insurance for projects that offer access to clean, affordable energy. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriations for the Department of State and United States Agency for International Development for fiscal years 2014 through 2015 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves and foreign governments to support clean cookstoves and fuels sector initiatives globally. The Department of Energy is authorized to appropriate funds for fiscal years 2014 through 2016 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. This includes conducting research to develop low-cost, low-emission cookstoves and biomass fuels. The Department of Energy is authorized to appropriate funds to support the development of low-cost, low-emission cookstoves and biomass fuels. The National Institutes of Health is also authorized to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to support health research and training for those at risk from household burning of solid fuels. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is authorized to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to evaluate cookstove and fuel programs for public health benefits and adoption determinants. Funding is available for fiscal years 2014 through 2015 for these activities. The Environmental Protection Agency is authorized to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves to conduct cookstove and fuel testing for environmental and health benefits. Funding is available for these activities for fiscal years 2014 through 2015. The National Science Foundation is authorized to conduct research on air quality and climate benefits of interventions for cookstoves and residential burning, as well as other activities under the Act. Funding is available for these activities for fiscal years 2014 through 2015. The National Science Foundation and the Department of Agriculture are authorized to receive funding for fiscal years 2014 through 2015 to collaborate with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. This includes supporting research on the benefits of clean cookstoves and fuels, providing technical expertise, and aligning with international efforts. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is authorized to receive funding for fiscal years 2014 through 2015 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. This includes monitoring global black carbon emissions, assessing climate impacts, and carrying out other activities under this Act. Peace Corps is also authorized to receive funding for similar activities. The Peace Corps is authorized to receive funding for fiscal years 2014 through 2015 to work with the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves. This includes training community members to select, construct, and maintain clean cookstoves and fuels, as well as providing ongoing support and grants to lower costs. Additionally, Congress recommends sufficient funding in future years for departments and agencies to fulfill commitments related to the Alliance.
